content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, simple and enough tests cases

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy but good question to test skills with hashset and for loop. Can be a good choice for Easy puzzle or code clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept contribution, because it looks like a ordinary simple task for code clash. I try it, it can be writen quickly
rip… These «Lucky number» isn’t a real term in Maths, but just something that can happen. Maybe you should change the title so as not to confuse it with «Euler's lucky number» ?
check guidelines for coc, linked somewhere in the editing GUI
I still dont get what u mean

https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines
read the whole thing before you contribute

Ig i know what u mean now. Do you mean that if ur code is like output Lucky u can get around 50%?

Kinda make sense but I think that the aim is to get 100% so  it doesnt matter a lot?

Or how do you suggest me to fix it?

(I think there are some few contribution also have this mistake)

Yes of course one would ideally try to get 100% on clashes, but binary output makes it :
1. possible to get 100% with rng (the chances are low but relatively high compared to clashes with a lot more different outputs possible)
2. unfairly rewarding for people that actually tried and gets less than ~50% (considering binary output is just hardcode printing an output)

Sadly, a lot of clashes that have binary output are available in CoC because 1. "moderators" sometimes don't know the guidelines of contribution (and sometimes don't bother to check) and 2. (iirc) the rule didn't exist some time ago. This is hard to fix because you don't get any reward for "fixing" a clash so moderators won't be bothered to do it unless rly necessary IMO.
***
About your clash, if you can't fix it, that means your clash might just not that good of an idea (which is kinda the case here : the code is a little too easy, just need to check if there's 6 and 8 or no 6 nor 8, not exactly a lot of coding rly). You can either try to put multiple numbers to test for (which is a lazy solution to binary output), or think of something else.
